title: Full access to any list
vulnerability_information:
Overview
==
The endpoint for adding a list collaborator lacks authorization checks. A regular Instacart user can add themselves as a collaborator to any list and thus get full control over that list.

How to Reproduce
==
1. Choose a list that you want to edit, for example the one with id = 10.
2. Log in to Instacart.
3. Copy the cookie and anti-CSRF headers from one of the requests. 
4. Send a request:
    ```
    POST /api/v2/list_users
    Host: www.instacart.com
    Content-Type: application/json
    Cookie: ...
    X-CSRF-Token: ...
    
    {"list_user":{"list_id":10,"email":"your@email.com"}}
    ```

5. Open `https://www.instacart.com/api/v2/lists/10` in browser and grab the list's token (`7bHoerQ` in this case).
6. Open `http://www.instacart.com/store/giant/lists/7bHoerQ/edit` in browser and do whatever you want to the list.

Proof of Concept
==
```
GET https://www.instacart.com/api/v2/lists/10

{"meta":{"code":200},"data":{"id":10,"name":"Test sameoldstory" ...
```

Security Implications
==
This vulnerability can be used to:
 * See metadata of a private list.
 * See the personal name of a list owner, even if they chose to hide it.
 * Change metadata and items or even delete any list.
 * Affect product promotion by messing with popular lists.
 * Perform website defacement and phishing attacks.
 * Enhance stored XSS attacks by embedding them into the popular lists.
vulnerability_information_html:
Overview

The endpoint for adding a list collaborator lacks authorization checks. A regular Instacart user can add themselves as a collaborator to any list and thus get full control over that list.

How to Reproduce

  1. Choose a list that you want to edit, for example the one with id = 10.
  2. Log in to Instacart.
  3. Copy the cookie and anti-CSRF headers from one of the requests.

  4. Send a request:

    POST /api/v2/list_users
Host: www.instacart.com
Content-Type: application/json
Cookie: ...
X-CSRF-Token: ...

{"list_user":{"list_id":10,"email":"your@email.com"}}

  5. Open https://www.instacart.com/api/v2/lists/10 in browser and grab the list's token (7bHoerQ in this case).

  6. Open http://www.instacart.com/store/giant/lists/7bHoerQ/edit in browser and do whatever you want to the list.

Proof of Concept

GET https://www.instacart.com/api/v2/lists/10

{"meta":{"code":200},"data":{"id":10,"name":"Test sameoldstory" ...

Security Implications

This vulnerability can be used to:

  • See metadata of a private list.
  • See the personal name of a list owner, even if they chose to hide it.
  • Change metadata and items or even delete any list.
  • Affect product promotion by messing with popular lists.
  • Perform website defacement and phishing attacks.
  • Enhance stored XSS attacks by embedding them into the popular lists.

activities.message: Would you mind, for transparency, inviting me to the original report so I can see it?
activities.markdown_message: Would you mind, for transparency, inviting me to the original report so I can see it?

activities.message:
I don't want to rush to conclusions, but this looks like a misunderstanding. The original report seems to have been closed as informative. Although I have no way to reliably verify this, I can see in my reputation log that I got zero increase for this report, which is exactly what happens when a report gets closed as duplicate of an informative.

And that's what I don't understand. This bug is definitely severe enough to not be closed as informative. I mean, using this bug the attacker can delete all Instacart lists, or replace all list images with something very unappetizing. Although I could imagine some other website not caring about this, I know that you care, because I submitted a similar report #162822 and it was accepted, even though it was less severe.

Also, judging by the Hackerone identifier, the original report was submitted on August 15th, which was 2 months ago. And after 2 months the vulnerability is still there. I find it hard to believe that you would knowingly keep a vulnerable endpoint in production for 2 months in a feature that is not even public yet.

Of course I wouldn't need to hypothesize if you invited me to the original report and thus gave me opportunity to understand the situation and defend my point of view.

activities.message: @sameoldstory I added you to the previous report.
activities.markdown_message: @sameoldstory I added you to the previous report.

activities.message:
Could you please reread my report?

From the comments to the report you added me to:
> this doesn't seem to allow you to actually change another user's list

The bug I reported does allow you to actually change another user's list.
activities.markdown_message:
Could you please reread my report?

From the comments to the report you added me to:

this doesn't seem to allow you to actually change another user's list

The bug I reported does allow you to actually change another user's list.

activities.message: Also please let me know if there was something particular in my report that made you think that I'm not able to actually change other user's lists, so that I can avoid misunderstandings like this in the future.
activities.markdown_message: Also please let me know if there was something particular in my report that made you think that I'm not able to actually change other user's lists, so that I can avoid misunderstandings like this in the future.

activities.message: @sameoldstory I am able to reproduce this. It does look like Privilege Escalation to me. I will reopen previous report and discuss with my coworkers.
activities.markdown_message: @sameoldstory I am able to reproduce this. It does look like Privilege Escalation to me. I will reopen previous report and discuss with my coworkers.

activities.message: Actually, previous report is different. I will just reopen this one instead. It did not mention the API call Privilege Escalation.
activities.markdown_message: Actually, previous report is different. I will just reopen this one instead. It did not mention the API call Privilege Escalation.

activities.message:
I think anybody can add anybody as a collaborator of any list with the method described, as long as providing list id, email and an x-csrf token. This is not a duplicate of #159771.
@hitomikt @mikeinstacart Could you double check?
activities.markdown_message:

activities.message: Hi @sameoldstory. I believe this should be fixed now, can you verify?

activities.message: Thanks for the confirmation, marking this as resolved.

summaries.content: Big thanks to @cxmcc-instacart for helping out. And big no thanks to @hitomikt for zero communication and no apology.
summaries.content_html: Big thanks to @cxmcc-instacart for helping out. And big no thanks to @hitomikt for zero communication and no apology.
